title: Carrying for mundane needs
vignette: Someone wants to move heavy furniture on holiday though it's not for food or holiday enjoyment.

options.text: Avoid such carrying; it's unnecessary labor.
Permit it if it eases household comfort.

title: Cooking for a non-member
vignette: A community member host prepares a holiday meal and a non-member coworker unexpectedly shows up.

options.text: Cook extra portions for the guest.
Refrain from cooking more since it's not for holiday use.

title: Egg laid on Holiday
vignette: A hen lays an egg on the holiday morning. May it be eaten right away?

options.text: Yes; it's fresh food for the day.
No; an egg laid on holiday is set-aside item.

title: Trapping an animal
vignette: A hunter finds a deer already caught in his net on holiday. Finishing the job requires tying it up.

options.text: Secure it to have fresh meat for the holiday.
Leave it until after the holiday.

title: Using stones as a grinder
vignette: Flour is running low and only two heavy rocks are available to crush grain on holiday.

options.text: Use them despite set-aside item concerns.
Wait until weekday to grind properly.

title: Borrowing water from a neighbor
vignette: Water is scarce, but your next-door neighbor has a well accessible only through his house.

options.text: Ask permission and carry water through his home.
Avoid carrying through private property on holiday.

title: Bringing gifts to a bride
vignette: Friends want to deliver wedding presents on holiday though it involves heavy carrying.

options.text: Bring them to honour the new couple.
Wait until after the holiday to avoid extra work.

title: Egg from a prepared bird
vignette: A hen was slated for ritual preparation before holiday but died unexpectedly and now its egg is found.

options.text: Eat the egg since the bird was designated for food.
Do not eat it; the death makes it questionable.

title: One symbolic boundary for consecutive holiday days
vignette: A two-day holiday begins Friday. Can one travel boundary suffice for both days?

options.text: Prepare separate symbolic boundarys for each day.
A single symbolic boundary may cover them all.

title: Lighting a cigarette from a holiday flame
vignette: Someone wants to smoke on holiday using an existing fire.

options.text: Permitted since transferring fire is allowed.
Prohibited because smoking is not a holiday need.

title: Soaking barley for animals
vignette: Farmers soak grain overnight to soften it for livestock, but doing so may look like weekday labor.

options.text: Soak it to feed the animals properly.
Avoid such preparation on the holiday.

title: Cutting hair on Holiday
vignette: A barber wants to serve customers during the holiday so they look presentable.

options.text: Allow haircuts for the sake of joy.
Haircuts are forbidden except for special cases.

title: Separating set-aside portions on the holiday
vignette: A basket of produce still needs portion set aside taken but guests are coming today.

options.text: Delay until after holiday despite inconvenience.
Separate it now so everyone can eat.

title: Heating bathwater for infants
vignette: Parents wish to warm an entire tub for babies though adults won't bathe.

options.text: Permissible for the children's needs.
Not allowed; only minimal washing is permitted.

title: Repairing a cracked dish
vignette: A clay bowl used for holiday meals breaks. Glue is available to fix it temporarily.

options.text: Fix it quickly to continue using the dish.
Do not repair dishes on holiday.
